data.title: Poems by Quasimodo Salvatore
data.meta_description: The Night Fountain: Selected Early Poems (Arc Translations) by Salvatore Quasimodo and a great selection of related books, art and collectibles available now at AbeBooks.com.
data.text:
Condition: Good. Most items will be dispatched the same or the next working day. A copy that has been read but remains in clean condition. All of the pages are intact and the cover is intact and the spine may show signs of wear. The book may have minor markings which are not specifically mentioned.

Softcover (Illustrated). Condition: Good. First Edition. Introduction by translator, translator's note. Illustrated paperback binding with white coloured titles to the front panel and back strip. Quoting from the rear panel blurb " . In 1959 Salvatore Quasimodo, the Sicilian poet, was awarded the Nobel Prize for 'his lyrical poetry which with classical fire expresses the tragic experience of life in our time'. No previous edition of his work has been a published in England. These new verse translations by Jack Bevan prove him to be, in the best sense, a contemporary poet, a major European voice, and a social and individual conscience Â a poet who must be heard and heeded." Rubbing of the book edges and panels with sunning of the back strip. Light browning of the text block edges and pages. The book has been stored improperly and feels a little "bumpy. Remnants of a sticker to be seen to the top right hand corner of the front panel. first edition by this publisher. Size: 12 mo (standard paperback). [6], 7 - 110, [2] pages, Please refer to accompanying picture (s). Quantity Available: 1. Shipped Weight: Under 1 kilo. Category: Poetry; Italy; Inventory No: 0289653.

Soft cover. Condition: Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Fair. First Edition. Pp. 48. Soft cover wraps are frayed, nicked and worn with edge loss. Published by the Italian Institute of Culture in Dublin on the occasion of the visit to Ireland of the poet Salvatore Quasimodo, February, 1963. The poems have been translated into Irish by Ethna Byrne Costigan and Mairin and Cearbhall O Dalaigh, and into English by G.H. McWilliam, Jennifer McWilliam, Ulick O'Connor and Lorna Reynolds. Salvatore Quasimodo (1901-1968) was a Sicilian novelist and poet. Small diminishing worm hole penetrates through the wraps and the first 4 leaves. In 1959 he won the Nobel Prize in Literature "for his lyrical poetry, which with classical fire expresses the tragic experience of life in our own times" Along with Giuseppe Ungaretti and Eugenio Montale, he was one of the foremost Italian poets of the 20th century.

Hardcover. Condition: Poor. No Jacket. Due to age and/or environmental conditions, the pages of this book have darkened. Has been glued back into its covers after being shaken loose. Solid binding. Moderate edgewear on the boards. Heavily shelf worn. Please note the image in this listing is a stock photo and may not match the covers of the actual item. Book.

Soft cover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Fair. First Edition. Pp. 48. Soft cover wraps are frayed and torn with edge loss. Front and back covers are torn from one another at spine. The book itself however is very good. Loosely inserted is 4pp. prospectus for a lecture by Dr. Gioia Gaidoni and Dr. Ethna Byrne Costigan at the Italian Institute. The title page is SIGNED BY THE POET. Published by the Italian Institute of Culture in Dublin on the occasion of the visit to Ireland of the poet Salvatore Quasimodo, February, 1963. The poems have been translated into Irish by Ethna Byrne Costigan and Mairin and Cearbhall O Dalaigh, and into English by G.H. McWilliam, Jennifer McWilliam, Ulick O'Connor and Lorna Reynolds. Salvatore Quasimodo (1901-1968) was a Sicilian novelist and poet. In 1959 he won the Nobel Prize in Literature "for his lyrical poetry, which with classical fire expresses the tragic experience of life in our own times" Along with Giuseppe Ungaretti and Eugenio Montale, he was one of the foremost Italian poets of the 20th century.

Soft cover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Fair. First Edition. Pp. 48. Soft cover wraps are frayed and torn with edge loss. Front and back covers are torn from one another at spine. The book itself hoswever is very good. Loosely inserted is 4pp. prospectus for alecture by Dr. Gioia Gaidoni and Dr. Ethna Byrne Costigan at the Italian Institute. The title page is SIGNED BY THE POET. Published by the Italian Institute of Culture in Dublin on the occasion of the visit to Ireland of the poet Salvatore Quasimodo, February, 1963. The poems have been translated into Irish by Ethna Byrne Costigan and Mairin and Cearbhall O Dalaigh, and into English by G.H. McWilliam, Jennifer McWilliam, Ulick O'Connor and Lorna Reynolds. Salvatore Quasimodo (1901-1968) was a Sicilian novelist and poet. In 1959 he won the Nobel Prize in Literature "for his lyrical poetry, which with classical fire expresses the tragic experience of life in our own times" Along with Giuseppe Ungaretti and Eugenio Montale, he was one of the foremost Italian poets of the 20th century.
